main_definition: In simple English, 'Harold' does not function as a commonly used idiom but can be a proper noun or part of phrases with various meanings.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A common given name originating from Old Norse meaning 'derived from Earl Harold', itself derived from the elements 'hari' (army) and 'wald' (ruler).
meanings_and_examples.example: 'Harold was born in 1985 and is named after his grandfather.'

meanings_and_examples.definition: A term used to refer to a person, typically male, when the specific name is unknown or not remembered.
meanings_and_examples.example: 'I can't recall where I met him, but he must have been Harold. He had that friendly demeanor.'

meanings_and_examples.definition: In certain historical contexts, particularly in medieval England, 'Harold' could refer to a noble or person of high status.
meanings_and_examples.example: 'The Battle of Hastings was fought between William the Conqueror and Harold II, King Harold II of England.'

meanings_and_examples.definition: In some regions, it may be used as part of place names (e.g., Harolds Cross in Ireland) or local businesses.
meanings_and_examples.example: 'I visited Harolds Cross last summer and enjoyed the scenic views.'
